info.text:
This tool provides a predictive model of pedestrian volume estimated using an Ordinary Least Squares (simple linear) regression method. The volumes estimated cover a 12-hour period (morning to evening).

This model is most useful for evaluating the relative level of pedestrian activity that would be expected under different conditions. It is based on a combination of environmental and demographic factors that showed a relationship with observed levels of pedestrian activity. The model may be applied to road and trail segments. For “average” facilities, this tool will generate plausible estimates, but it does not deal well with unique or atypical facilities or locations, and some facilities may show negative values.

We have included the Ordinary Least Squares pedestrian model in the Non-Motorized Toolkit primarily for completeness (all models in the UMN report linked in the tool documentation have been implemented). You should use the Negative Binomial version of the model (which forces values not to be negative) if you would prefer to see results that only contain positive numbers, and that thus might be directly compared to your own counts.

The coefficients for the model were estimated by a team from the University of Minnesota (UMN) based on counts collected in Minneapolis, and published by the UMN Center for Transportation Studies in July 2012. The model implementation presented here was developed by the Open Technology Group (Morrisville, NC) under contract with the Federal Highway Administration.

The full report on the study and model development is available in the tool Documentation Links.

output.description: You may override the default field name in which results from this tool are reported by entering a different name here.  The name you enter may be adjusted so it is not the same as any fields already in your input data.

elements.description: Field name that will contain 12-hour pedestrian volume
elements.label: Result Field
elements.name: result

output.name: results
output.label: Result Variable

elements.name: Pctnonwhite
elements.description: Fraction of neighborhood residents that are non-white

elements.name: PctU5_O65
elements.description: Percentage of neighborhood residents over 65 or under 5

elements.name: Pctw4ormore
elements.description: Percentage of neighborhood residents with a college education

elements.name: MedHHInc
elements.description: Median household income ($1000s per year)

elements.name: Crime
elements.description: Average number of violent crimes/year (in neighborhood)

elements.name: PDperkm2
elements.description: Population density in persons per square kilometer

elements.name: LUMix
elements.description: Measure of mixing of land uses (range 0-1); see report

elements.name: WatDist_km
elements.description: Distance from nearest body of water, in kilometers

elements.name: CBDdist_km
elements.description: Distance from central business district, kilometers

elements.name: EmployAccess
elements.description: Number of jobs accessible via a transit trip of 30 minutes or less.

elements.name: Principal
elements.description: Principal arterial street (1/0)

elements.name: Arterial
elements.description: Arterial street (1/0)

elements.name: Collector
elements.description: Collector street  (1/0)

elements.name: BusRoute
elements.description: Presence of one of more bus routes (1/0)

elements.name: OffstreetTrail
elements.description: Off-street trail (1/0)

input.description: Specify the location of each required parameter field in the input file. You may ignore certain properties, and you may also choose to specify a global value to be applied to all features (Global values are listed in the next section).
input.label: Input File Fields
input.name: data

input.description: These are the estimated coefficients for the Ordinary Least Squares Pedestrian hourly volume model. They are presented for reference only and should not be changed without a full model re-estimation.
